awd_titl_txt: MRSEC: UW Molecular Engineering Materials Center
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract: The University of Washington Molecular Engineering Materials Center (UW MEM-C) addresses fundamental problems in materials research that push the frontiers of science, accelerate the development of future advanced technologies, and address challenges of broad national and societal importance. MEM-C's research activities stress innovation in the design, discovery, and application of complex electronic and photonic inorganic materials with low dimensionality. MEM-C also spearheads education, training, and outreach programs to prepare tomorrow's leaders in science and technology, with signature programs focusing on promotion of (re)entry of veterans into science/technology/engineering/mathematics (STEM) career tracks, and early recruitment/mentorship of students to STEM from underrepresented/underserved regional high schools. Additional activities include REU/RET/REM programs, regional K-20 outreach, regional partnerships for public engagement, and interdisciplinary curriculum development. MEM-C further strengthens ties between UW and industrial, international, and National Laboratory partners through sponsored internships and collaborations. MEM-C shared facilities provide lasting infrastructure that promotes the activities of the Center as well as of the broader campus and regional materials science communities.

Technical Abstract: MEM-C's research involves two interdisciplinary research groups (IRGs): IRG-1: Defects in Nanostructures addresses the scientific challenge of engineering unprecedented physical properties into inorganic nanostructures by controlling defect formation and doping, and exploits these emergent properties to develop new technologies ranging from laser cooling to solar concentration; IRG-2: Layered Quantum Materials creates and studies new forms of quantum matter in atomically layered materials, emphasizing phase transitions in these materials, with potentially disruptive impact on energy and information technologies. Both IRGs integrate materials innovations with theory/computation at the interface of materials science, chemistry, physics, and engineering to identify and explore fundamentally new physical phenomena and to advance these scientific frontiers toward new applications. A competitive seed program supports high-risk high-reward projects in emerging areas. These activities are developing the materials underpinnings of future advanced technologies and simultaneously providing interdisciplinary education and training of the nation's future leaders in science and technology. Participants in the Center include 15 senior investigators, 5 postdoctoral associates, and 14 graduate students from 5 departments and 1 National Laboratory.

por.por_cntn:
The University of Washington's Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC), referred to as the UW Molecular Engineering Materials Center (MEM-C), aimed to accelerate the development of future energy, quantum/classical information, and quantum/classical sensing technologies through design, discovery, and deployment of complex electronic and photonic materials while simultaneously preparing today's science and engineering trainees to be tomorrow's innovators and leaders in industry, national laboratories, education, and other STEM-related sectors. MEM-C performed transformative research that advanced the frontiers of science by developing complex nanoscale matter with unique physical properties and a deep fundamental understanding of their governing principles. Over 54 graduate students and postdocs have completed their training in this highly interdisciplinary research during this award period. To accelerate the translation of new materials, technologies, and expertise, MEM-C forged ties with industrial and national laboratory partners. Through outreach, MEM-C inspired youth to join in solving the next generation's scientific and technological challenges. The Center facilitated transitioning of adults into the technology workforce through veteran recruitment, and enhanced diversity in STEM through recruitment and retention of underrepresented minorities in Center activities.

 

Intellectual Merit. MEM-C's research activities were anchored by two synergistic Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs) that shared the common objective of engineering complex electronic materials at the nanoscale: IRG-1: Defects in Nanostructures engineered unprecedented physical properties into inorganic nanostructures by controlling defects and exploited these properties for future technologies from laser cooling to solar quantum cutting. IRG-2: Layered Quantum Materials created new quantum matter from atomically layered materials and their multilayer structures, with potentially disruptive impact on energy and information technologies. Both IRGs were aligned with the NSF's "Quantum Leap" Big Idea, including through development and fundamental investigation of point defects in nanostructures for quantum sensing and single-photon emission (IRG-1) and development of layered 2D materials capable of exploiting quantum interactions to control the behaviors of quantum particles and energy at atomic length scales (IRG-2). Both IRGs used machine-learning algorithms for predictive design and high-throughput data processing, in alignment with the NSF's "Harnessing the Data Revolution" Big Idea. These IRGs were complemented by a vibrant portfolio of 25 Seed and iSuperSeed projects that allowed the Center to rapidly pursue new cutting-edge research opportunities and to introduce new capabilities and personnel, moving the Center in new directions. iSuperSeed funding was used to support an interdisciplinary thrust to accelerate materials discovery through data-enabled microscopy and spectroscopy. The Center also established a new MEM-C Shared Facilities offering the broader community open access to state-of-the-art research instrumentation. 

The intellectual merit of the Center is reflected in the portfolio of new materials that it produced and in its scholarship and research advances described in over 168 (and counting) high-impact publications that acknowledge this award in leading international journals. Of these, over 40% were primarily supported by the Center, with over 79% of these primary publications coauthored by 2 or more MRSEC faculty.

 

Broader Impacts. MEM-C launched and led a multifaceted education and training program that successfully engaged K-12 students and teachers, undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs in an integrated approach to promote STEM learning. MEM-C's education activities engaged diverse participation, valued professional development for varied career paths, developed core technical competencies, and fostered professional soft skills, preparing participants to meet the full array of 21st-century needs. Center programs streamlined engagement of MEM-C trainees and faculty in effective broader-impact activities to grow STEM participation at the K-12 level, provide early research experiences, and increase awareness of connections between basic research and society in the general public. MEM-C launched a popular NanoCamp! outreach activity that brought hands-on STEM-engagement activities to over 1000 K-12 students over the course of the award. MEM-C launched a suite of signature activities specifically to attract URMs and veterans into the center, including through its REU/RET/ALVA programs and via partnerships with synergistic on-campus entities. The Center launched a new regional conference, Nanocrystals Northwest, engaging students, faculty, and researchers from PUIs, R1 institutions, national laboratories, and industry in center-led research and education activities. MEM-C launched two new NSF-funded Partnerships in Research and Education in Materials (PREM seeds) with minority-serving institutions at the University of Hawai'i, Mānoa and the University of Central Florida, actively building these partnerships through research/education collaborations and personnel exchange. MEM-C launched a new self-sustaining Shared Facilities that offers users access to unique and workhorse research instrumentation.


Last Modified: 12/27/2023
Modified by: Daniel R Gamelin
por.por_txt_cntn:
The University of Washington's Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC), referred to as the UW Molecular Engineering Materials Center (MEM-C), aimed to accelerate the development of future energy, quantum/classical information, and quantum/classical sensing technologies through design, discovery, and deployment of complex electronic and photonic materials while simultaneously preparing today's science and engineering trainees to be tomorrow's innovators and leaders in industry, national laboratories, education, and other STEM-related sectors. MEM-C performed transformative research that advanced the frontiers of science by developing complex nanoscale matter with unique physical properties and a deep fundamental understanding of their governing principles. Over 54 graduate students and postdocs have completed their training in this highly interdisciplinary research during this award period. To accelerate the translation of new materials, technologies, and expertise, MEM-C forged ties with industrial and national laboratory partners. Through outreach, MEM-C inspired youth to join in solving the next generation's scientific and technological challenges. The Center facilitated transitioning of adults into the technology workforce through veteran recruitment, and enhanced diversity in STEM through recruitment and retention of underrepresented minorities in Center activities.

IRG-2: Layered Quantum Materials created new quantum matter from atomically layered materials and their multilayer structures, with potentially disruptive impact on energy and information technologies. The intellectual merit of the Center is reflected in the portfolio of new materials that it produced and in its scholarship and research advances described in over 168 (and counting) high-impact publications that acknowledge this award in leading international journals.
